sub_title: PRISM Project Manager  at Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources, Rwanda, SPIU IFAD Funded Projects

company.name: Ministry of Agriculture & Animal Resources, Rwanda, SPIU IFAD Funded Projects

profile_positions.description:
Partnership for Resilient and Inclusive Small Livestock Markets (PRISM). The Project is funded by IFAD (Co-financed by Heifer International and Government of Rwanda) and ENABEL. It operates in 15 Districts out of 30. The main implementing partners are Heifer International for IFAD Funded Interventions and VSF-Belgium for ENABEL Funded Interventions, and Rwanda Agriculture and Animal Resources Development Board (RAB) for both Donors. It covers Pig, Poultry, Goats, and Sheep Value Chains. 
The overall objective of the project is to reduce poverty by empowering poor rural men, women and youth to participate in the transformation of the Rwanda livestock sector and to enhance their resilience. The Project Development Objective is to improve food and nutrition security and incomes of poor rural households through better performance of the value chains.
profile_positions.title: PRISM Project Manager

profile_positions.description: The aim of this study was to compare environmental impacts of milk produced in contrasting systems based on a literature review of life cycle assessment (LCA) studies. We reviewed 14 studies based on four criteria: the main output of a production system under study was milk, the production system under study was situated in an organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country, the study included at least all processes from cradle-to-farm-gate, and the study compared at least two contrasting dairy production systems. We classified the studied systems based on the production methods (conventional or organic), and type of diet (concentrate-based or grass-based). This review resulted higher global warming potential (on average 10% higher), acidification potential (5% higher), eutrophication potential (37% higher), energy use (67% higher), and lower land use (31% lower) per unit of milk for conventional compared with organic systems. The higher impacts in case of conventional systems were explained mainly by a higher use of mineral nitrogen fertilization and a higher use of processed feeds. Furthermore, results showed a higher global warming potential (on average 26% higher), acidification potential (78% higher), eutrophication potential (35% higher), energy use (179% higher), and a lower land use (6% lower) per unit of milk for concentrate-based compared with grass-based systems. The higher impacts in case of concentrate-based systems were also explained mainly by a higher use of mineral nitrogen fertilization and a higher use of processed feeds. Except for global warming potential, results should be interpreted with care because impacts were compared in a few studies only. Methodological choices, such as choices on how to account for emissions from land use changes, can lead to differences in LCA results. Therefore, further harmonization of LCA methodology can improve comparison of LCA results.
profile_positions.title: MSc Research Project (Major): Comparing environmental impacts of dairy cattle production systems
